response: I'm not sure I could say much on that particular matter.

I'm pretty sure the guy's guilty. The neighbor heard the gun shot at 5:36 PM. He claimed he had stayed late at work and didn't get home until after 7, but none of his coworkers could corroborate his story.
What actually happened is that he spent that hour and a half getting his story straight for the authorities.
What an awful fate. I just hope we can bring her killer to justice.
He seemed generally on the level. He seemed to have a real disdain for the defendant during his testimony though.
I remember reading an article in the paper about allegations of her stacking juries. I don't think anything ever came of it though.
I'd consider myself a believer in the concept of small-goverment. This country has too many rules and regulations that only serve to hinder small businesses.
That said, when it comes to matters of the criminal nature, there's no question. Murder is murder, my friend. No way you're weasling outta that one.

The prosecution's main point regarding the firearm that was allegedly used to commit the relevant crime is that he bought the shotgun specifically to use in the murder. A pawn shop three blocks from his house reported having sold a firearm of the very same model to the defendant two days prior.
I'd consider myself an expert on all manner of firearms. Ask me any question about the history of firearms and I can probably answer it.It's a hobby of mine, for sure.

text: Should we get started then?
I suppose the level-headed thing to do is discuss the shotgun the defendant used in the crime.
It was an L-FAD 960.
Thinking about it now, aren't those things super rare?
Funny.
I didn't realize it before, but the L-FAD 960 is a collector's item. It was one of the HS-series models that skyrocketed in price on the speculative market last year.
I'll put it this way. If he were to buy one of them today, it would cost him that entire inheritance he was chasing and then some.
The fact that he owns one of these means he must have bought it before the price spike.
It's possible he didn't know it was valuable at the time. Or maybe he did know and was holding onto it to see if it would go up even further.
His prints were on the gun.

Not a single friend or family member questioned could corroborate him having owned a gun of any sort. And he had no record of having bought the gun. This leads me to believe he bought it very recently and for this particular purpose.
Not a single friend or family member questioned could corroborate him having owned a gun of any sort. And he had no record of having bought the gun.

Well that may be the case, but it means that the defendant has no answer to the prosecution's witness. The pawn shop owner positively identified the defendant in the court room as having bought that very same gun from him two days earlier.
They did prove he bought it recently. The pawn shop owner identified the defendant in court as having bought that very same gun from him two days earlier.
That makes the murder premeditated.
They did prove he bought it recently. The pawn shop owner identified the defendant in court as having bought that very same gun from him two days earlier.
Agreed. This is not a character trial.
Wow, you saw the aftermath of the crime?
You don't cuff a suspect with their hands in front. The whole point is to prevent the suspect from using their hands effectively. Cuffing in front just forces them to have their hands close together.
Well you have to admit there's room for reasonable doubt.

This entire conversation is specious. Just because you don't think he would do such a thing because you judged him from across a court room and decided he's on the level, doesn't mean he didn't have a motive.
Seemingly normal people do terrible things all the time. And speculating as to who would or would not do this is a matter of pure philosophy.
And philosophy is not what we're here to perform today.
That's right! He called the defendant a slacker and that the project "would hopefully be in better hands moving forward."

acquitEntirely: I hope we are doing the right thing.
acquitInheritance: It's clear he did not fire the gun and I don't buy the motive for the crime.
acquitCoworker: It's clear he did not fire the gun and I don't think he was there when the crime occurred.
chargeWithAssault: Guilty of assault, not guilty of murder.
completelyGuilty: He's clearly guilty. A man like that needs to be locked away.
guiltyShotgun: Regardless of the other facts, he definitely fired the shotgun.
guiltyMotivePlusOpportunity: Regardless of the other facts, he had both motive and opportunity.
